AreaChart.description: An area chart is similar to a line chart, but the area between the line and the axis is filled. It emphasises the magnitude of values.
AreaChart.usecase: Often used to show accumulated totals or to highlight the volume under a trend, especially over time or continuous domain.
AreaChart.applicability: Use when you have a continuous or time-series domain (x-axis) and numeric values for one or more series.

format.title: <Title of Area Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object contains the X-axis key and Y-axis key. The Y-axis values should be an array of numeric values (for multiple series). If only one series, array with a single numeric value is permissible.

example.title: Monthly Sales Overview
example.description: This area chart represents the monthly sales figures for the year 2023.

BarChart.description: A bar chart displays categorical data as rectangular bars whose heights (or lengths) correspond to data values. Bars may be vertical or horizontal.
BarChart.usecase: Commonly used for comparing values across categories or discrete groups (e.g., revenue by region, counts per category).
BarChart.applicability: Use when you have categorical X‐axis and a single numeric measure (or multiple numeric series) per category.

format.title: <Title of Bar Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object contains the X-axis key and Y-axis key. The Y-axis values array supports multiple series; if single series, array with one numeric value.

example.title: Quarterly Revenue Comparison
example.description: This bar chart compares revenue generated in each quarter of 2023.

LineChart.description: A line chart plots a series of data points connected by line segments, typically to show trends over a continuous domain. The horizontal axis is usually a continuous variable (often time), and the vertical axis is the value.
LineChart.usecase: Ideal for visualizing how a value changes over time or another continuous scale (e.g., sales over months, temperature over days). Supports multiple series.
LineChart.applicability: Use when you have a continuous/time domain for X-axis and numeric Y values across one or more series.

format.title: <Title of Line Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object contains the X-axis key and one or more Y-axis keys. Each Y-axis key must map to a numeric value.

example.title: Website Traffic Over Time
example.description: This line chart shows the number of visitors and page views over the first half of 2023.

PieChart.description: A pie chart divides a circle into slices to represent parts of a whole. Each slice’s angle (or area) is proportional to its value.
PieChart.usecase: Ideal for showing how a total is broken into categories (e.g., market share, budget allocation). Best for a small number of categories; not suitable for time series.
PieChart.applicability: Use when you have categorical data where values sum to a meaningful whole and a small number of categories.

format.title: <Title of Pie Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object contains the name key (category) and value key (numeric) that represents part of the whole.

config.innerRadius: <Inner radius for donut charts, if applicable>

example.title: Market Share Distribution
example.description: This pie chart illustrates the market share distribution among different companies in 2023.

DonutChart.description: A donut chart is a pie chart with a hole in the centre (inner radius > 0). It provides the same data mapping but leaves room for a central label or key metric.
DonutChart.usecase: Use when you want the aesthetics of a pie but also want to highlight a central metric or label.
DonutChart.applicability: Same as PieChart but when you want to highlight a centre statistic or have a chart with a hole.

format.title: <Title of Donut Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Similar to PieChart. The config must specify `innerRadius` to produce the donut effect.

example.title: Revenue by Product Category
example.description: This donut chart shows revenue distribution by product category for 2023.

Histogram.description: A histogram shows the distribution of a continuous numeric variable by grouping it into bins and plotting counts of observations in each bin.
Histogram.usecase: Use when you have one numeric variable (continuous) and you want to reflect its frequency distribution.
Histogram.applicability: Use when you have a single numeric variable and want to show its distribution via bins (counts per bin). Usually implemented via BarChart with bins.

format.title: <Title of Histogram>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object is a bin with label and count. The Y-axis must be numeric counts.

example.title: Score Distribution
example.description: Histogram of test scores in bins of size 10.

ComposedChart.description: A composed chart allows mixing multiple chart types (e.g., bar + line + area) over the same domain for richer context.
ComposedChart.usecase: Use when you want to show more than one type of measure in the same chart with a shared axis (e.g., revenue as bars, margin as line).
ComposedChart.applicability: Use when you have a common domain (X-axis) and multiple measures where different visual types make sense for each measure.

format.title: <Title of Composed Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object has the X-axis key and multiple measure keys. The `series` array determines which field uses which chart type.

example.title: Revenue vs Margin Over Time
example.description: This composed chart shows revenue (bars) and margin percentage (line) over months.

ScatterChart.description: A scatter chart displays points defined by two numeric values (and optionally a third for size or color). It’s used for correlation or distribution analysis.
ScatterChart.usecase: Use when you want to show the relationship between two numeric variables (or three with size/color).
ScatterChart.applicability: Use when you have two or more numeric axes (X and Y, optionally Z) and you want to show their relationship rather than simple category-value comparisons.

format.title: <Title of Scatter Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object has numeric values for both X and Y axes. Optionally size or category keys can be included.

example.title: Height vs Weight Scatter Plot
example.description: This scatter plot shows relationship between height (cm) and weight (kg) for a sample dataset.

RadarChart.description: A radar chart (aka spider or web chart) compares multiple quantitative variables across one or more observations on a radial layout.
RadarChart.usecase: Use when you have multiple metrics for each entity (e.g., skill ratings across categories) and you want to compare them across entities.
RadarChart.applicability: Use when you have several quantitative variables per category/entity and the comparison across entities is the goal.

format.title: <Title of Radar Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object has the angleKey (category) plus numeric values for each series to compare.

example.title: Skills Matrix
example.description: This radar chart compares skill ratings of two team members across subjects.

FunnelChart.description: A funnel chart visualises a sequential process (e.g., lead → opportunity → customer) and shows drop-off between stages.
FunnelChart.usecase: Use when you have ordered stages of a process and want to show the quantity at each stage and how it declines.
FunnelChart.applicability: Use when you have sequential categories (stages) and numeric values for each stage.

format.title: <Title of Funnel Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object has a stage name key and numeric value key.

example.title: Sales Funnel
example.description: This funnel chart shows pipeline conversion for Q1.

StackedBarChart.description: A stacked bar chart is a variation of the bar chart where multiple numeric series are stacked on top of each other per category, showing total plus component breakdown.
StackedBarChart.usecase: Use when you have categorical X-axis and multiple numeric measures per category that you want to display both individually and aggregated.
StackedBarChart.applicability: Use when you have one category axis and multiple numeric fields per category, and you want to show part-to-whole or breakdown stacked within categories.

format.title: <Title of Stacked Bar Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects. Each object has the category key and multiple numeric fields (one per series) that will be stacked. The `series` array lists each numeric field to use.

example.title: Revenue & Cost Breakdown by Region
example.description: This stacked bar chart shows revenue (blue) and cost (red) for each region, stacked for total view plus breakdown.

TreeMap.description: A treemap visualises hierarchical or nested data by representing each node as a rectangle, with children nested inside parent rectangles. The size of each rectangle corresponds to a numeric value.
TreeMap.usecase: Use when you have hierarchical categories with numeric values for each leaf or node (e.g., budget by department and team, file system size by folder).
TreeMap.applicability: Use when you have hierarchical data (parent → children) and numeric size metrics; not just flat category-value pairs.

format.title: <Title of TreeMap>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object may contain nested `children` arrays. Each leaf object must have the `valueKey` numeric field indicating size.

example.title: Budget Allocation by Department and Team
example.description: This treemap shows budget size allocated across departments and sub-teams.

SankeyChart.description: A Sankey diagram visualises flow from one set of nodes to another, showing amounts flowing through links. The width of links is proportional to the quantity.
SankeyChart.usecase: Use when you want to show how values move through a system (e.g., traffic flows, user conversion paths, resource transfer) or many-to-many relationships between nodes.
SankeyChart.applicability: Use when you have a network of nodes and numeric flows (links) between them, rather than simple category-value pairs.

format.title: <Title of Sankey Chart>
format.formatInstructions: An object with `nodes` array (listing node names or ids) and `links` array with `source`, `target` and numeric `value` for each link. Numeric `value` shows flow magnitude.

example.title: Website Traffic Flow
example.description: This Sankey diagram shows how website visitors move from referral sources to landing pages to purchase.

ParallelSetsChart.description: A parallel sets diagram visualises multi-categorical data across dimensions, showing categories and how they cross between dimensions (alternative to parallel coordinates for categorical data).
ParallelSetsChart.usecase: Use when you have multiple categorical dimensions (e.g., user segment → product category → region) and you want to show flows or relationships between categories across those dimensions.
ParallelSetsChart.documentation: Not a native built-in component of Recharts; treat as custom implementation or fallback to other visualisation.
ParallelSetsChart.applicability: Use when you have multi-dimensional categorical data and want to visualise relationships across those dimensions rather than numeric trends.

format.title: <Title of Parallel Sets Chart>
format.formatInstructions: Array of objects where each object has values for each categorical dimension plus a numeric value representing size of flow or count.

example.title: User Journey Across Segments
example.description: This parallel sets diagram shows how users move from segment to product to region.
